cluster_relations.rel_desc: Urban legends influence people within communities by capturing their imagination and curiosity.
remarks: Slight abstraction: using 'communities' to stand in for globally distributed people.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Different cultures influence how tales evolve over time.
cluster_relations.subject_class_label: Community Social Groups in Urban Legends

qualifiers.TemporalQualifier: as tales are retold over time
qualifiers.ConditionExpression: to suit the interests and fears of different cultures

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Urban legends are described as having an impact on popular culture.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject exerts an influence or impact on the properties, behavior, or development of the object.
args.justification: All three relations describe a directional influence or impact (urban legends on communities, cultures on tale evolution, urban legends on popular culture). They share the same causal-impact semantics with consistent directionality, so a single canonical predicate 'influences' can be applied.

Each relation expresses that one entity influences or shapes another (social groups, communities, cultural domains, or narrative evolution). Grouping them under the broader class 'influence_relation' captures this shared impact-oriented semantics across different subject/object types.

Influence here denotes that the subject contributes causally to changes or characteristics of the object (e.g., cultures causing tales to evolve, urban legends shaping communities and popular culture). This fits best under a broad causal/impact category.
